./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Prosperius - Rules
Introduction
In Prosperius, each player acts as a Mayor that guides their fledgling village to become a thriving town. Players build locations and take actions to create valuable trade goods. Trade is non-optional in Prosperius; your villagers will trade goods if they need them or have surplus. The more prosperous a village, the more people populate it - and the more its citizens demand. The player who develops the most prosperous village wins!
Overview
Prosperius is a game of worker placement and trade. Players take turns placing their workers, also known as their villagers or population, on actions such as Build and Gather. As a village grows, so too does its available actions. Each new location provides a new action that can be performed.
As a village consumes and trades goods, it becomes more prosperous. Increasing in prosperity causes a player to gain Prosperity (points), thereby increasing in tier. Each increase in tier raises the village’s population, unlocks new locations that can be built, and places greater demands on the growing village.
Game End
The game ends when any player has at least 100 Prosperity points at the end of a round. The player with the most Prosperity wins! If there is a tie, the tied players share in a victory.

Modes of play/number of players
Prosperius is designed for 2-5 players. The game can be played competitively against each other with all amounts of players, but a two-player game plays best in Cooperative Mode.

components.html.title: Game Components
components.html.body:
Game Components

Pieces
Player Boards
The Cards

pieces.html.title: Pieces
pieces.html.body:
Pieces
Villagers/Population (4x5)
Each player starts with 2 Villager Tokens and receives up to 5 as their village advances through the Tiers.
 [add image]
Prosperity Markers (4)
[add image]
Goods (oodles!)
Most of the pieces in Prosperius are goods, sometimes called resources. These are gathered, produced, and traded.
[add image]
Some goods are designed to be carried by your villagers. These goods can be placed directly onto Villager Tokens to be carried around. For example, clothes indicate that your population works effectively in the cold.
Education is not a "Good", but it is also carried by your villagers to indicate that they are permanently educated.
[add image]
Animals
Animals are not considered goods. They cannot be demanded or traded. There are sheep, pigs, and cows.

Straggler Token (ie. first player)
The Straggler Token indicates which player goes first in a round.
[add image]

game_boards.html.title: Game Boards
game_boards.html.body:
Game Boards
Prosperity Track
Score (Prosperity) is kept on the Prosperity Track. There are coloured indicators for each Tier of your village, as well as for the end of the game. [add coins image]

Player Boards
Each player receives a board. The board is where all of a player's locations are placed. It also contains terrain and resources.

Terrain
Plains
Plains are the default terrain type, indicated only by a lack of other terrain. Grassland is mostly flat and is easy to build on. Trees can be planted on plains.
Mountains (impassable)
Cannot be built on, but often contain stone and metal resources that can be gathered. Some buildings must be built beside mountains, eg. Ore Mine.
Rivers (impassable)
Cannot be built on, except for bridges, which then allow for movement through the tile. Some locations must be built beside rivers, eg. Fishing Nets.
Forest
Can only be built on if their forest is cut down, or only just growing back (Saplings). The Woodcutter's Shack can be used to both chop down Forests and plant Saplings. Forests regrow automatically over time, but only if they aren't built over. Trees can be planted here if the forest has been cut down.



Resources
All resources can be gathered by the player, though usually inefficiently.

Ore
Animal herds (meat)
Wheat
Wood
Not directly found on the board, but can be acquired by chopping down a Forest.

cards_overview.html.title: The Cards
cards_overview.html.body:
The Cards
Most of the complexity of Prosperius comes not from its rules, but from the cards.
Season (one card, front and back)


Town Events (~10 cards)

Town Market (1 card)

Start Cards (3 cards)
![start_cards]
[add home card]
Locations (oodles!)

setup.html.title: Setup
setup.html.body:
Setup
Set up your village
For each player:

Pick one of each of the two player board halves. Decide as a group whether or not to do them randomly. Place both halves together in front of you so that the border is on the outside.
Take one of each of the following cards: Village Centre, Gather, Stockpile, and Home.
Place your Village Centre on the big X on your Player Board.
Place Home partially underneath your player board so that only the top two green rows are showing.
Place the other two cards near your Player Board.


Take 1 Wood and 2 Bread pieces from the supply. Place them in your Stockpile.
 
 
 

Take two population tokens of your preferred colour from the supply.
Place the corresponding coloured marker on the Prosperity (score) board at 0 points.
Ensure the game’s resource/good pieces are accessible to everybody; they will be using them regularly.

Set up the cards

Sort the game’s locations by removing any cards that require more players than are playing. Some cards specify player numbers on the back at the bottom. Then group the remaining cards by colour (ie. tier).
Lay out all cards from the first tier (indicated by a green stripe) in such a way that they are accessible and easy to read for all players. Place the remaining cards in a pile to the side.
Put the Season card in the middle of the playing area with the Summer side face up. The first turn will be summer.
Reveal the Food Surplus Town card. Place it beside the season card. Shuffle the remaining Town cards and place them underneath or nearby.
Put the Town Market card in the middle of the playing area so that everyone can reach it.

Pick the first player

The player who had the most prosperous weekend goes first. Place the Straggler Token in front of them.

main_actions.html.title: The Main Actions
main_actions.html.body:
Your Main Actions
As a Mayor in Prosperius, you will always have two special actions available: Build and Gather.
Build
The Build action comes from your Village Centre. It allows you to begin the construction of a location. You must place a worker on Village Centre to use the action as normal, and it can be used any number of times per round.

Building Requirements
Note that certain locations have an Education requirement in the top-right of their card (but not on the back). This means that in order to begin the construction of that location, you must use an educated villager to take the Village Centre action.
Other locations require that you own a particular location at the time you begin construction. The location must also be completed. For example, to begin construction on the Master Tailor, you must have a completed Tailor ("Must own Tailor").


Location costs are in the top-right of the card. However, you may begin construction of any available location in the central supply (taking into account its education/location requirements), regardless of whether or not you have the required goods. The location will complete automatically when the needed goods are placed on the card.
In order to construct a location, use the Village Centre action. Then select a location from the central supply and place it face-down on your player board on a valid reachable tile.
A tile cannot be built on if it:

has a Mountain, River, or Forest on it, or
is across a river (unless you have a Bridge).

You can build on Saplings, Ore, Wheat, etc. Any such items on a tile are discarded if building over them.
Completing a Location
A location makes progress on its construction by placing resources on the symbols visible on the back-side of the card. How these resources are gained does not matter. In fact, having an under-construction building actually creates demand for those resources (see the Trade Phase).
After the last required resource is placed on the location, it is flipped face-up either:

right away, if the last resource was placed during the Action phase, or
at the end of the phase otherwise.

The resources should be discarded to the central supply immediately - they have been used.

Note: a few locations - such as a Farm - do not have building costs. They can simply be flipped face-up immediately when they are constructed.


Gather
The Gather action comes from your Gather card. You may use it any number of times per round. Place a worker on it to perform one of the four listed actions.

Gather Actions
Gather actions are the actions listed on the Gather card. The Ox Cart, for example, allows for the taking of two Gather actions on the same tile of your Player Board. The actions listed are your choices and can be used in combination.

When using Gather, place your worker on the tile being gathered from rather than the Gather card itself. This makes it easier for you and other players to see what your villager actually did.

Ox Cart
The Ox Cart is single use, and therefore you should place your worker on the card itself to indicate that it cannot be used again this round.
Note
The Stockpile provides no actions, but should be used to place any surplus goods.

game_phases_overview.html.title: Gameplay Overview
game_phases_overview.html.body:
Game Round Overview
There are 5 phases each round. Most of the phases are quick. The Act Phase is where you will spend most of your time.
Round order

World Phase
(new tier setup if necessary)
Pick first player
Flip/resolve season card


Passive Phase
Perform passive actions


Act
Take actions
Return workers home


Trade
Take turns offering goods


Prosper
Calculate points
Discard food eaten
Discard excess food
Discard one clothing

world_phase.html.title: World Phase
world_phase.html.body:
World Phase
In Prosperius, the world evolves around you. The World Phase is as follows:

If a new Tier has been reached:
Reveal a new Town card. Discard the previous Town card.
Reveal new locations for the new Tier by adding them to the central supply.


Determine the new first player to be the player with the lowest score.
If there is a tie, the previous first player passes the token to the first player on their left that is tied with them.


Flip the Season card and immediately perform its effects.

passive_phase.html.title: Passive Phase
passive_phase.html.body:
Passive Phase
The passive phase is short but important. Any automatic effects in your village happen at this time.
Perform any passive effect (for which you meet the conditions) on your cards. They should be highlighted to be as clear as possible.
Some examples:

Animals reproduce in sheep/pig/cow pastures if there are at least two of them.
Add fish to Fishing Nets cards.
Vegetable Field provides one or more Vegetables to your stockpile.
...etc.

act_phase.html.title: Act
act_phase.html.body:
Act
Phase order
The Act phase is where most of your time will be spent.

Starting with the first player, each player takes a single action (see Taking an Action below) using one of their unused workers.
Continue clockwise until all players have used their population to take actions.


Once everyone has completed all possible actions, return your villagers home by placing them on the circles on your Home card.
Discard degrading items.
Eg. if your population was wearing clothing, discard one clothing (it has been tattered over the course of the season).



Taking an action

Place one population on a card that allows for an action to be taken.
This means that:
All conditions are met (eg. it is currently the correct season, and so on).
All costs can be paid. Your card should have placed on its demand icons the goods that will be spent for the action.




Tell the next player you are done your turn (as you are just collecting pieces).
Immediately perform the action.
Pay the cost.
Do what the action says, including all modifiers.
Eg. if the card says "+3 Grain", take 3 Grain from the bank.


Then, fulfill your demand!
Set aside any goods that are demanded by your villagers. This includes food up to your current population. See the relevant reference card for a complete list.
Place any gained goods onto any demand indicated on your cards.
Place any remaining goods on your stockpile. These can be traded.

trade_phase.html.title: Trade
trade_phase.html.body:
Trade
Trade makes Prosperius tick. It's designed to move quickly, and for good reason - you don't get any choice in the matter! It's all up to your villagers' needs and wants.
Demand
Demand comes in various forms, but it always represents the same thing: a need or want for a good of some kind. Your villagers will automatically demand a number of goods such as Food, Clothes, and all Luxury Goods. Your locations might demand certain goods to complete their construction or to take actions on the location.
Your villagers' needs take priority over the locations in your village. Similarly, your village as a whole takes priority over other villages. Therefore it is only possible to trade goods with other players if you have surplus goods.
In other words, when determining demand, use the following rules for importance:
Your population > your locations > other villages
Your village is always open to trading for goods that they need or want, or for trading away surplus goods. You do not get to hold back goods from another player, or to 'demand' goods that your villagers and locations do not explicitly demand.

Fulfill your demand! (the golden rule)
If you acquire goods through producing, gathering, trading, etc., you should immediately fulfill your village's demand. Any large uncovered image of a game piece is considered to be demanded. Eg. if you chop down trees and have an under-construction location that requires wood, immediately place wood on the card's demand indicators.
Similarly, set aside the food your village will use this round in your Home card. This food is not available for trade (as it will be eaten).

Goods can be moved between demand. For example, if you have two locations under construction, one of which has wood placed on it, you can move the wood to be on the other location.
Required Goods
Some locations are inoperable without a specific good. For example, a Smithy is useless without 1 Wood (for the furnace) and 1 Metal (for the Tools). To make this as clear as possible, any such demand is highlighted to indicate its necessity:






Notice that the Smithy requires 1 Wood and 1 Metal, but it functions at a higher output with Tools, more Metal, and Education.

Food Demand
Your villagers prefer eating quality food over Bread, no matter what (eg. Fish, Fruit, Meat, etc). This is true even if you would gain no extra points by consuming quality food instead. Your bread will last forever, unlike most other food, making it an excellent backup food. See Bread is Special for details.
Similarly, your villagers prefer to eat bread than Wheat. This is true even if you would gain no extra Prosperity by consuming bread. Lastly, luxury food (such as Cream) supersedes quality food.
The priority when determining what can be eaten, then, is as follows:
Luxury food > Quality food > Bread > Wheat

Food trade order
Note that food must be offered in the same order when trading. Otherwise, you could potentially sell all of the above types of food to the same player!

Trading goods
Before anything else, make absolutely sure that your own demand, both on your population and locations, is satisfied.
One at a time, starting with the Straggler:

Offer each good in your stockpile to other players.
If offering food, use the order described above.


Players that demand that particular good speak up.
Starting from the player on your left and going around, attempt to fully satisfy that player's demand.
Take 3 points for each good you sell to that player. Luxury goods are worth more!
The buying player simply takes the good and immediately satisfies their demand.

The order of goods (usually) doesn't matter, but the order of players does! You may find that you can't sell a good because another player sold it first, or that other players get the goods you wanted. The Straggler therefore has the best chance of selling their goods.

prosper_phase.html.title: Prosper
prosper_phase.html.body:
Prosper Phase
Your villagers now get to eat (hopefully!) and prosper.

Subtract Prosperity based on your current Prosperity score. The amounts are on the Prosperity score board.

Gain one Prosperity for each needed/wanted good by your villagers. All such goods should be lined up beside your population.

Eg. 1 point for each:
quality food consumed
clothing worn
wine drunk
...Etc!


Refer to the reference card if unsure about which goods your villagers need/want.


Discard all food eaten this round.

Discard any quality food in your stockpile - it has spoiled.

Discard one clothing.


Food
There are two types of food in Prosperius: quality and non-quality food.
Each quality food consumed generates a point and prevents starvation.

They are discarded at the end of the round if stored in your stockpile (spoilage).

Each non-quality food consumed only prevents starvation.

Bread and Wheat are the only types of non-quality food. However, Bread is special.

Bread is Special
Bread was the base of nearly every meal for medieval Europeans. To represent this, each quality food consumed makes one consumed bread count as quality food.
Note that your villagers still prefer quality food over bread when it comes to trading. See Food Demand.

Examples
Your village has 5 population.

They all consume bread
=> counts as 0 quality food (no quality food)


One villager consumes fish/fruit/etc., the other 4 consume bread
=> counts as 2 quality food (1 quality food + 1 bread)


Two villagers consume fish/fruit/etc., the other 3 consume bread
=> counts as 4 quality food (2 quality food + 2 bread)


They all consume fish/fruit/etc.
=> counts as 5 quality food (all quality food)




Starvation
If any of your population fails to eat, they will starve next round and your village immediately loses Prosperity.
For each population that does not eat:

-1 Prosperity immediately

Moreover, if ANY of your population does not eat, place aside one villager next round as Starving. Starving villagers:

Cannot perform actions
Eat and demand as normal

If all of your workers eat, you will not have any Starving villagers on the following round. You should never have more than one Starving villager.
Luxury Goods
Luxury goods generally provide +1 Prosperity for consumption. Note, however, that:

Luxury clothing counts as clothing and a luxury good. It therefore provides +2 Prosperity.
Luxury food counts as food and a luxury good. It therefore provides +2 Prosperity.

Examples

A Tier 3 village has four population (-8). Three of them eat quality food (+3), and one eats non-quality food (+0). They are all clothed (+4) and two are educated (+2).
This amounts to +1 Prosperity total (9-8).

prosperity.html.title: Prosperity
prosperity.html.body:
Prosperity (points)
You've gained some Prosperity by trading or satisfying the needs and wants of your village. More Prosperity means you advance through the game, but also makes it more difficult to maintain your position.
Prosperity points are referred to on cards with the following icon:

For example, a Stone Bridge provides 6 Prosperity when built.

Growing pains
After you gain enough Prosperity to cross a tier threshold, your village has become prosperous enough to attract another villager. However, your villagers now also expect a certain standard of living.
Two things can happen on the next round of play:

Your village's population increases by one. That is, you can take an extra Worker Token.
Add that Tier's location cards to the central supply (if not done previously).

Tiers
Tier 1: 0 Prosperity
  2 population
Tier 2: 25 Prosperity
  3 population
Tier 3: 45 Prosperity
  4 population
Tier 4: 70 Prosperity
  5 population
100+ Prosperity - Game over!
Losing Prosperity
It can sometimes happen that you will lose Prosperity and return to a previous Tier. You should discard a worker and any goods on the Worker Token.

cards_in_detail.html.title: Reading the Cards
cards_in_detail.html.body:
The Cards - In Detail

Title

The name of the card. Cards are sometimes referred to by other cards.


Building cost

In the top-right of the card, though sometimes empty if the location is free. Describes how many of each resource is required to complete them. Also includes whether or not the location requires education to build (which is NOT on the card's back).


Demand

Demand describes when a village is willing to trade for a good from another player, and is unwilling to give up a good to other players.
When demand is fulfilled, it gets a game piece placed on it. It is unfulfilled when empty.
Any large image of a game piece is considered to be demanded - unless it is covered by that good.
See the Trade phase for a full explanation of demand.


Adjacency requirements

Some locations need to be built beside (not on!) a specific terrain type such as Mountains or Rivers (eg. Fishing Nets must be beside a river). This requirement can be found in the bottom right of the card. Eg.




Effects

Actions

Performing actions is where players will spend most of their time. An action is taken by a population/worker. An action that can be taken only once per round is indicated by a single worker icon, whereas an action that can be taken multiple times is indicated by three workers.





Conditions

An action or effect may only apply during a specific season, or require an educated worker to complete. This requirements will be listed on the left of the action.


Costs

Some effects or modifiers require the consumption of a particular good in order to function. They are inoperable without that good because it must be paid as a cost. These are always found in parenthesis. With the Iron Mine, 1 Wood must be expended to gain 4 metal.



Passive Effects

Passive effects are those that happen automatically under certain conditions. These are performed during the Passive Phase.


Active Effects

An active effect requires an action from a worker to take effect.


Modifiers

A modifier is not an action unto itself, but it adds to the effects of an action.
For example, a Wheat Farm generates 3 Wheat as an action. However, if tools are consumed as part of that action, an extra 2 Wheat are produced, leading to a total production of 5 Wheat.



General Effects

Anything in italics is a general effect for that card. Eg. +3 Prosperity when built or Must build within 2 spaces of a completed location.






The Golden Rule of Card Games
If a rule on a card contradicts a rule in the rulebook, the card takes precedence.

smooth_play.html.title: Making the game run smoothly
smooth_play.html.body:
Smooth Gameplay
Below are some tips on how to ensure the game runs smoothly.

The trade phase can be fast if you want it to be. Remember that there are no decisions to be made!

Fulfill your demand ASAP. Other players will want to know what goods your village needs. Consider enforcing this as a rule in your games.

If a player is not in the room, they can still participate in trade! Any large icon indicates demand, so it can be determined at a glance.

Start taking your action after the player to your right has taken their action. Do not wait for them to pick up their goods! The game is designed for players to take one action at a time for exactly this reason.

Do not let players go back on their previous actions. If people are brand new to the game, however, consider being lenient if changing their mind would not affect the game.

Play Cooperative Mode with two players!

terminology.html.title: Terminology
terminology.html.body:
Terminology
Population/worker/villager
One of your 5 playing pieces. The term workers is generally used as population in the context of taking actions, ie. chopping down trees.
Thematically, each villager represents a number of people.
Visitor
A visitor is a villager from a village other than your own. For example, the School gives Prosperity to its owner for each visitor use. This only provides Prosperity when used by villagers belonging to other players (not your own).
Complete (location)
A location on your player board that has been flipped face-up (after having all required resources placed on it). Your Village Centre is a completed location, but your Gather card is not (it is not on the player board).
Under Construction/Incomplete
A location that is face-down. It has been started, but has not yet been completed by flipping it over to be face-up.
Discard
Put back into the central supply of goods or cards.

Location
Any card that can be placed on your player board. Eg. a Farm and a Smithy are both Locations.
Central Supply
Refers to either the cards in the middle or the goods in the bank (belonging to no player), depending on context.

cooperative.html.title: Cooperative Play
cooperative.html.body:
Cooperative Play
Although Prosperius can sometimes feel cooperative, you are still competing against your opponents in the regular mode of play. Cooperative Mode changes that.
Select a scenario from the options below. Each scenario has a corresponding summary card(s) that can be used for easy reference.
Population Influx
Populations are booming. Your villages need to grow enough to attract larger populations before neighbouring towns render you irrelevant.
Have each village meet the Tier requirement by the given rounds.



Tier
# Rounds (Easy)
# Rounds (Medium)
# Rounds (Hard)




2
6
5
4


3
9
9
7


4
11
11
9


✓
13
13
11



Failure
Each village that fails to be at the required Tier by the given round immediately loses 5 Prosperity. This will make it that much harder to meet the next Tier requirement.
The Great Cathedral (idea)

Players work together to finish building The Great Cathedral in X rounds.
Requires:
loads of basic resources.
multiple stages of building (tracked on a card/sheet), some of which require education.
Luxury goods.
manual labour (taking actions on the cathedral itself)
Get bonuses (eg. Prosperity) for completing the Cathedral on time.
This should help to keep the game moving, rather than only slow it down!





Black Plague (idea)

Track sickness by heart tokens.
People get sick (use Heart tokens, ideally only one per player).
As soon as someone hits Tier 2, one village each round has one of their population become sick.
Any village already with a sick population gets one more of their population sick.
If all of their population are sick, that player loses 5 Prosperity and that disease spreads to their left instead.


Sickness can spread from village to village through trade.
Players must visit the Town Physician for health supplies to keep the disease from spreading and/or heal their villagers.
Uses separate Town Event deck with Disease Spreads cards.


Track health with heart tokens and have bad things happen depending on number of unhealthy population in villages.

Baby Boom (idea)
Your villagers have come back from the war and population is rising.
Ideas:

Players gain all 5 population after the any player hits Tier 2.
Players must then all finish the game within some number of rounds.

faq.html.title: FAQ
faq.html.body:
Frequently Asked Questions
Q: Do I need quality food if I already have 100% quality food but am relying on Bread?
A: Yes. Even if you have 4 villagers with 2 Bread and 2 Fish, meaning you will gain full points for quality food this round, your villagers will still demand quality food to replace the Bread.
Q: Why is it recommended to play Cooperative Mode with 2 players?
A: Prosperius thrives on trade. With only two players, preventing your opponent from succeeding is just as valuable as succeeding yourself. Players therefore often build locations and never use them, only supply themselves with clothes, and so on. The game therefore slows down, especially at the end.
In short, feel free to play - it's still fun! - but it's a different kind of game.
Q: Can I play Cooperative Mode with more than 2 players?
A: Absolutely! The game will be easier, however, so try to play at a higher difficulty.

example_game.html.title: Example Gameplay
example_game.html.body:
Example Game (first few rounds)
Round 1
World Phase

Flip season to winter (if it isn't already because it's round 1).
Flip the Town Event deck to reveal a No News is Good News (nothing happens).

Passive Phase

Nothing to do yet.

Act

Take a Village Centre action to build a Farm, then wait for your next action.
Gather a Vegetable to ensure your Bread stores lasts longer.
Line up your available food right away!


Take back pieces when everyone is done.

Trade

There is probably nothing to trade at this point, unless certain locations were built and specific resources were gathered.

Prosper

Eat your food (1 Bread, 1 Vegetable) and gain 2 Prosperity because the Vegetable elevates the Bread to being quality food!


Round 2
World Phase

Flip Season to winter (if it isn't already because it's round 1).
Flip the Town Event deck to reveal a No News is Good News (nothing happens).

Passive Phase

Nothing to do yet.

Act

Take a Village Centre action to build a Farm, then wait for your next action.
Gather a Vegetable to ensure your Bread stores lasts longer.
Line up your available food right away!


Take back pieces when everyone is done.

Trade

There is probably nothing to trade at this point, unless certain locations were built and specific resources were gathered.

Prosper

Eat your food (1 Bread, 1 Vegetable) and gain 2 Prosperity because the Vegetable elevates the Bread to being quality food!


Round 3
World Phase

Pick a new first player if the previous first player is tied or no longer in last (passes to the left to the player with the fewest points).
Flip Season to Summer. No need to grow saplings/trees/wheat or replenish animals.

Passive Phase

Nothing to do yet.

Act

You build the Hunting Cabin (someone else has already taken the Bakery!).
Use your Farm while it's still summer.

Trade
*
Prosper
*

Round 4
World Phase
1.
Passive Phase
*
Act
1.
Trade
*
Prosper
*

advanced.html.title: Advanced Rules
advanced.html.body:
Advanced Rules
These rules are only to be used if players have played the game more than once. Do not introduce these to beginners - they will only complicate the learning process.
Replacing/removing locations

Can remove a location when constructing a new one.
Optionally take one resource from the central supply that the location needed for construction.
Remove the card and place back in the central location supply.
Place the new location where the old one was.


Varied food - Optional
Players can an extra Prosperity for each quality food eaten past the first one. Bread does not count.

Example: With 4 population, the player ate 2 Fish, one Bread, and one Vegetable. That is two quality food types (ignoring Bread), so the player gains one Prosperity for having a nuanced diet.

Varied food does not affect trading in any way.
